captions.text:
They will cheat you,
hurt you, lie!

You don't have any friends.
Nobody likes you.
You're a liar and a thief.

Where would you be without me?
Gollum. Gollum.
Leave now and never come back.
Leave now and never come back!
We told him to go away.

comments.text:
BooksI think tolkien would be very pleased to know how far his imagination 
has influenced individuals around the world. I am grateful for the movies 
because I don't think the newest generation of American students have 
proper reading and comprehension skills to enjoy the Lord of the Rings 
books. Here's some trivia I just learned in the past few years. Did you 
know Tolkien and CS Lewis were friends and that Lewis encouraged Tolkien to 
write LOTR?
comments.author: Larry Morris

comments.text:
I'm actually a little obsessed. I read the books 43 years ago and was never 
so grateful for any movie as I was for this trilogy.I even have an LTR 
phone case (with the ring on it - but I can't read elvish; I only know what 
it says), a mug that says (I love you like a hobbit loves 2nd breakfast), 
etc. etc. Do you have the extended version? Love the whole expose on 
Tolkien (his thoughts, philosophies, etc.).

comments.text:
Don't get your comment here. Faramir led the rangers; Faramir let frodo go. 
Boromir died after trying to take the ring from Frodo.
comments.author: Gail Tanner

comments.text:

comments.author: Larry Morris

comments.text: +Gail Tanner ... Oh. Never thought of that.
comments.author: The Dark Weapon

comments.text:
+The Dark Weapon No one ruined Smeagol's progression. He was always going 
to be 2 halves no matter what happened. Gandalf said he still had a part to 
play. Had Smeagol progressed, there wold have been no Gollum and without 
Gollum, the ring would have not gone into the fires of Mt. Doom. Frodo 
would have kept it. In that way, Gollum/Smeagol was also a "hero." His role 
was necessary.
comments.author: Gail Tanner

comments.text: +Gail Tanner Yea but he still ruined Smeagol's social progression.
comments.author: The Dark Weapon

comments.text:
+The Dark Weapon The leader was Faramir. What I was saying is that yes, 
Faramir captured them and took them to be delivered to his father (Lord 
Denethor) at Minis Tirith. BUT then he saw the encounter between the witch 
king and Frodo and let them go. He then understood the quest. Faramir's 
fellow ranger said "You know the laws of your father and if you let them 
go, your life will be forfeit." And Faramir said "then it is forfeit." 
Farramir could have kept the ring and sent it to his father (who definitely 
would have kept the ring). Instead he "gave up" the ring. Boromir, 
Faramir's brother, tried to steal the ring from Frodo earlier and was 
killed. Only Faramir was willing to give it up and let the quest continue.
comments.author: Gail Tanner

comments.text:
Even before Smeagle had touched the ring he was willing to kill for greed. 
It was not even him that found the ring he just wanted it for his birthday 
so he killed the 'friend" and took the ring. This was not a kind hearted 
river folk that was corrupted it was a greedy, evil filled creature that 
the ring easily took over after he had it. So the only one responsible for 
Smeagles actions and fate was smeagle. 

Most any sacred site is jealously defended and Smeagle was fishing in a 
pool the Rangers thought of as sacred. They had every right to kill him but 
did not. Yes they beat him but again he was fishing in a sacred pool not 
some random stream. They could have killed him but did not. 

As gail stated Faramir even forfeited his life to let them go. And it was 
rather obvious smeagle was not free or even close to free of the ring. He 
is like any addict that has a moment of clarity then as soon as things get 
hard again he is right back after the ring and scheming to kill Frodo and 
Sam. This after Sam explained to him that "Master" was just trying to save 
Smeagle.

For Smeagle to break free of the ring there would have to be some good in 
him and there never was. He got himself into this with greed and lived that 
same way with the ring. One moment of clarity does not redeem you for a 
life time and then some of green and hate.

Blame who you want for Golems down fall and death in the end but had he not 
killed his friend for a ring he barely saw he would not have been in this 
mess. And before you start in on how the ring corrupted him making him kill 
his friend, if his had that much influence on him that kind of proves he 
was full of greed and hate to start with.

There is an entire chapter of the book they skipped for the move where they 
stop by someones house on the way to the Inn of the Prancing Pony. They 
showed him the ring, he picked it up and held it then gave it back with no 
ill effects. This was to prove that the ring only corrupted those with dark 
desires. This is why both Frodo and Bilbo were able to be in contact with 
it if with few ill effects for a long time yet Smeagle succumed to it 
without even touching it (if you want to go with the argument that it did 
infact make him kill his friend).

So who is to blame for Smeagle and his fate? No one but Smeagle. Feel free 
to blame who you want but we all know now who is really to blame. But feel 
free to be like him and blame other for your own faults.

comments.text:
It's amazing how far the technology has come in the Hobbit movies from 
this. Whilst the character still looks great, I've been spoiled by the CGI 
in the Hobbit films so I can definitely tell that the Gollum in this scene 
is CGI whilst I could almost believe the Gollum in The Hobbit is real due 
to their new technology (PBR, sub-surface scattering, CAT rigging and 
secondary mesh deformation). Then again, give it another 10 years and I'll 
probably be saying the same thing about the current CGI :P﻿

comments.author: Kristine Silmaro

comments.text:
+Caswell39A Oh, the arrogance of people telling others what they should or 
should not be interested in or outgrow. Simply because YOU might not enjoy 
something does NOT under any circumstances mean others should not. Who the 
hell do you think you are? I'll tell you what you come off as: a 
shit-headed conservative with his head up his ass who thinks he can dictate 
the lives and interests of others to his whims. Bud, it's time to get the 
hell off your high horse and come back down to earth, because you're not as 
clever or intelligent as you seem to think yourself to be. The very fact 
you keep coming back to a video on a subject you have no interest in speaks 
for itself. You are grasping for attention, for a fight, to try and prove 
yourself as smart as you like to think yourself. In reality, you only prove 
to the rest of us that you're a pigheaded troll desperate for attention. I 
hope you will "outgrow" your fat head and your self perceived superiority 
and save us all from your actual ignorance.

PS: Please for the love of all things good in this world NEVER reproduce.
comments.author: riotracer

comments.author: Kristine Silmaro

comments.text:
+Kristine Silmaro I could not have said it better myself. I would have 
attempted, but sometimes the astounding ignorance of some people just 
shocks me to the point of being speechless. Is that guy FOR REAL?! You did 
a good job and said exactly what I wanted to say. And on better news, there 
was a LotR marathon on today! Guess what I did? Enjoyed these fantastic 
movies, you bet! I never get tired of the magnificence.
comments.author: riotracer

comments.text:
+riotracer IKR? *high-five through the screen*  I tried to explain to this 
guy already that motion-capture is completely different from cartoon 
animation, but he just refuses to listen. I can understand it if this guy 
doesn't like fantasy stuff like Lord of the Rings. But he intentionally 
chooses to remain ignorant of how the movie was made and continues to 
pretend that he knows how all this movie/animation stuff works. Oh, well. I 
tried, and now I know it's useless. I'm just gonna give it up here -_-
comments.author: Kristine Silmaro

comments.text:
+Caswell39A No, I never said this stuff was real. Gollum's voice for sure 
is real though. Like I said, I have proof that his voice is real whereas 
you have none that it is fake. As for the animation, I clearly said that 
there was animation done. But it is motion-capture animation. That type of 
animation is based off of a real, live performance, not like cartoons are. 
Completely animated cartoon characters are based off of drawings. All of 
Gollum's movements and his animation is based off of a real person, and a 
live action performance. Sure, there is a conceptual drawing for what 
Gollum looks like. But in motion-capture, the animators take the original 
drawing, and apply it to the live performance of Andy Serkis. That's just 
the technique applied in motion-capture. And if you don't even know that, 
then you don't know much about movies in general. Because practically every 
movie with a CGI character started using motion-capture animation once Lord 
of the Rings had so much success with Gollum.

And if you're gonna bring up that thing about Gollum's eyes, then yes, they 
are big. But obviously, you haven't read the books, because his eyes and 
his weird, distorted body are what make up Gollum's original character. 
Yes, I know it's unrealistic. But that's the way Tolkien describes him. And 
if I seem like a Lord of the Rings/Peter Jackson fanatic to you, then so be 
it (btw, I acknowledge that King Kong isn't such a great movie). It's 
better than being an ignorant douchebag who pretends to know how everything 
works without even going behind the scenes of the movie they are ranting 
about. 
Furthermore, I acknowledge that this "fantasy stuff" is what I'm into. But 
I also like movies that are set in the real world. I also like movies that 
are truly the big budget ones, that are 500 million-dollar projects. As 
long as they are good movies. And if you're really gonna go into this whole 
"this movies sucks because it used millions of dollars on advertising and 
selling" argument, then you are basically hating on every single film of 
the modern world. If that's the case, then simply don't watch movies. Tis 
as simple as that.

Do you honestly expect for a movie to NOT use a lot of money on 
advertising? What's the point of making a film if you don't try to get 
people to watch it? And for a story like Lord of the Rings, which by the 
way already had a HUMONGOUS fanbase because of the books, how could they 
NOT try to sell out the theater when so many people already love the story? 
How could they NOT spend a lot of money to try and make the movie good when 
so many people have such high expectations?
Either way, that doesn't change the fact that Lord of the Rings still used 
a lesser budget than any other movie during that time period, both in the 
making and in the advertising. So you're argument is negated anyways.

Your argument is based around the fact that you don't like this 
"unrealistic, fantasy" stuff. If that's true, why even go through the 
bother of watching it then?
comments.author: Kristine Silmaro

comments.text: BTW; do you two also think the characters of "Frozen" are equally real?
comments.author: Caswell39A

comments.text:
Rio- your attitude makes Froddo cry! Tolkien failed in teaching you to be

comments.author: Caswell39A

comments.text:
+Kristine Silmaro Owned. Wish I could like your comment a thousand times. 
This +Caswell39A baffoon is so ignorant it makes me want to cry in despair. 
A repulsive reminder of the stupidity that stalks our society.
comments.author: riotracer

comments.text:
Kristine - you come across like a religious fanatic. No computer 
enhancement and no CGI? Do you actually think this stuff is REAL? If it was 
all so brilliant - why is it they have to spend 100's of millions of 
dollars to flood the movie screens - yes, they BUY up all the theatres so 
YOU see it - and keep other work out? Please post here about the mature 
movies without dragons, hobbits and bad bug-eyed cartoons you admire - 
maybe some low budget personal favorites you found without popular 
 advertising to telling you how to think. (BTW; if Jackson is your God, you 
must feel likewise about his equally brilliant multi-million dollar "King 
Kong". You can't say you didn't like it or you'd be what I'm called - a 
"troll" for having the courage to admit this fantasy stuff is plagiarized 
and cheesy.  (If you're young, I understand your admiration and apologize. 
You'll outgrow this Froddo stuff,  just as you have Harry Potter.
comments.author: Caswell39A

comments.text:
+Caswell39A Wow, this comment just goes to show that you know nothing about 
Lord of the Rings. They didn't use ANY computer voice distortion. That was 
all the actor, Andy Serkis. How do I know that? I just watched the special 
features behind the scenes. I saw with my own two eyes and heard with my 
own two ears, Andy Serkis record this scene. It sounded exactly as it does 
now, no voice distortion required. And by the way, this animation is not 
cartoon, stupid. This was MOTION-CAPTURE. Do you even understand what that 
is? In essence, the animated characters are actually physically and 
literally acted out by real actors. The animators use the actor's body 
motions during a scene as a base to animate. And for your information, Lord 
of the Rings was one of the first to use motion-capture.
And don't act as if you're any more mature than a 15 year old, when you 
start ranting on a film you know absolutely nothing about. What millionaire 
made this?! Peter Jackson at the time he made these movies was not a very 
well known director. He had little to no money or credit among other 
directors. He had to convince New Line (which was considered an inferior 
studio at the time), to endorse these movies based on the stories' own 
merit. 

In fact, you seem to know so little about Lord of the Rings, that you don't 
even know that it was all shot in New Zealand. Nobody thought that 
something like Lord of the Rings could be shot anywhere but Hollywood. And 
if this really WAS an ego project for a multi-millionaire studio and 
director, they would have definitely done it in Hollywood. But no, instead 
Peter Jackson chose to do it in New Zealand, a country who almost nobody 
paid attention to in terms of film-making. And he used a large cast of 
no-name actors, actors whom nobody had really heard of in Hollywood.

Lastly, Lord of the Rings used a lesser budget than almost any other movie 
made (in Hollywood) that year, so the success these films have had has 
nothing to do with money. Before you start trying to make yourself feel 
like a smart-ass, why don't you try doing your research first? You don't 
know the efforts and work people put into Lord of the Rings. Hell, you 
haven't even tried to learn about it. So what makes you think you could be 
a good judge of anything this movie has done or accomplished?
comments.author: Kristine Silmaro

comments.text:

feed it

comments.text:
Lord of the Rings was the first to use roto-animation and motion capture 
for a CGI character. In fact, they created that type of animation. So 
saying that the effects are cheesy is totally untrue. Because any movie 
you've seen which uses the same type of effects as Lord of the Rings are 
the ones who are copying Peter Jackson's work. Therefore, those special 
effects are the ones that are cheesy.

comments.text:
+goofysjes1 Smeagol was a Stoor Hobbit, one of three races. The Harfoot 
Hobbits (commonly known as the ones in the shire) The Fallowhide Hobbits in 
which the Tooks, Bilbo and Frodo had relation to, they were also taller in 
appearance and were very adventurous. Smeagol was a stoor, one of the river 
folk and i think he resided in the Gladden Fields area not far from Lorien. 
He lived with his clan there ruled (i think) by his grandmother. After the 
ring took hold of him, making him do bad things like stealing from the 
tribe and that, he was banished. There is a quick reference to his 
grandmother in the first hobbit movie. I've not read the books for a while 
so this info may not be totally accurate. :)

Why would it have mattered if he had been in makeup? Hell, makeup would 
never have made him look close to how gollum is supposed to look. This IS 
motion captured though. That voice and all the motions and acting are 
straight from Serkis himself. He should have won an award for it 
regardless! That man can act anything!

comments.text:
It's like any other inner conflict....some obvious and some subtle, you 
know?
Anyone ever been addicted to drugs and gone through the justifications it 
takes to do what is needed to get more? 
It's the very same thing.
It all boils down to a sequence of conscience vs. our invented 
justifications.﻿
